author: By The New York Times
title: Profiles of Change: For 7 Women, a Heartfelt Cause Became a Mission
description: Leaders from around the world explained how they took their passions and concerns and turned them into action.
content: A financial administrator with deteriorating sight seeks help at an advocacy organization for visually impaired people and rises to become its chief executive. A former government spokeswoman with a love of cooking starts a restaurant to train refugees in culinary skills. A Lao weaver hoping to preserve a traditional craft creates a way to support it. Seven women from around the world explain how they took their passions and concerns and turned them into action. The interviews were edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 27, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 27, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Stephen Colbert Cancels ‘Late Show’ Episodes After Rupturing Appendix
description: Colbert posted on social media that he was recovering from surgery and unable to host this week.
content: Stephen Colbert canceled his “Late Show” episodes for the week as he recovers from surgery for a ruptured appendix, he announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices Search for Middle Ground on Mandatory Sentences for Gun Crimes
description: A federal law imposes a mandatory 15-year sentence for possessing a gun after committing three serious drug offenses. But which offenses count?
content: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday over which drug offenses trigger mandatory 15-year sentences under the Armed Career Criminal Act, which is a kind of federal three-strikes law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahita Dua
title: ‘My Patient Did Not Have to Die the Way She Did’
description: We need to create a gold standard of care to treat patients with peripheral artery disease.
content: In the fall of 2021, a soft-spoken woman in her 60s came to the emergency room where I worked, complaining of pain in her foot. When I examined her, I could see that I would need to amputate the infected leg immediately, or she risked sepsis and death. I amputated her leg that night. She died 14 months later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: There’s a Lot Riding on Black Friday and Cyber Monday
description: The White House and economists will be closely watching the annual shopping events for insight into what the data says about the state of the consumer.
content: Black Friday and today’s Cyber Monday shopping bonanzas hold outsize political significance this year with the retailing events emerging as key recession and inflation indicators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: How the Biden Administration Took the Pen Away From Meta, Google and Amazon
description: The administration isn’t letting the tech giants write the rules of global trade. Good.
content: One reason that the idea of free trade has fallen out of fashion in recent years is the perception that trade agreements reflect the wishes of big American corporations, at everybody else’s expense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Hamas Releases More Hostages, and More
description: Plus, a shooting wounds three Palestinian men in Vermont, and Young Thug’s lyrics are allowed as trial evidence.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti
title: Female Rangers ‘Don’t Go All Alpha Like the Men’ to Protect a Forest
description: Rather than take a confrontational approach with trespassers looking to farm or log in a tropical rainforest in Indonesia, teams of women rangers try dialogue first.
content: Riding her motorbike while balancing a backpack, a wok and a sharp cleaver, Asmia expertly maneuvered her way up a dangerous cliffside: a three-mile trip along a precipitous dirt path, barely 40 inches wide, to reach the mouth of the forest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Nom Nom Nom. What’s the Deal With Cookie Monster’s Cookies?
description: If you have ever wondered what the “Sesame Street” muppet is really eating, we have the answer.
content: Years ago, a reader wrote probing for details on a mystery that had vexed him: What’s the deal with the cookies that Cookie Monster eats?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $5 Million Homes in California
description: A 2023 house in Palm Springs, a hillside home in Malibu and a hacienda-style retreat in Sonoma.
content: This house is behind the gates of Parc Andreas, a small community about 10 minutes from the center of Palm Springs. It was designed with locally sourced materials and comes equipped with 28 solar panels to offset energy costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Mark Landler
title: Amid Parthenon Dispute, Sunak Cancels Meeting With Mitsotakis
description: After the prime minister of Greece called for the British Museum to return the Parthenon marbles, his British counterpart abruptly called off their meeting.
content: For the past two years, Greece’s government has conducted delicate negotiations with the British Museum over the future of the Parthenon marbles, the ancient Greek antiquities brought to Britain in the early 19th century by Lord Elgin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg, Yara Bayoumy and Vivian Yee
title: Hamas and Israel Extend Cease-Fire for 2 Days, Qatar Says
description: The extension, and another exchange of hostages and prisoners, raised hopes that more people would be set free and more humanitarian aid would reach people in the Gaza Strip.
content: Israel and Hamas agreed on Monday to extend by two days a cease-fire that has brought a measure of calm to the Gaza Strip after seven weeks of intense warfare, the Qatari government said. The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and allow more aid into the beleaguered territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: A Palestinian Author, Ahed Tamimi, Faces Indefinite Detention After Hearing
description: She is one of the highest-profile Palestinians arrested by Israel since Oct. 7 during a sweeping and contentious crackdown aimed at deterring attacks.
content: It was around 4 a.m. when Nariman Tamimi’s daughter, Ahed, roused her from sleep and told her that Israeli soldiers had surrounded their home in the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Olivia Bensimon
title: 5-Year-Old Boy and Parents Are Stabbed to Death in Bronx Building
description: The child and his mother were found in their apartment, and the boy’s father lay dead in a hallway. Police investigators were questioning a relative.
content: A 5-year-old boy and his mother were found fatally stabbed in their Bronx apartment on Sunday, and the boy’s father was found stabbed to death in the hallway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden’s Absence at Climate Summit Highlights His Fossil Fuel Conundrum
description: The president is facing some pressure to focus on oil drilling and gas prices at home, while boosting climate ambition on the world stage.
content: President Biden signed the country’s first major climate law and is overseeing record federal investment in clean energy. In each of the past two years, he attended the annual United Nations climate summit, asserting American leadership in the fight against global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Edward Wong
title: Inside U.S. Efforts to Untangle an A.I. Giant’s Ties to China
description: American spy agencies have warned about the Emirati firm G42 and its work with large Chinese companies that U.S. officials consider security threats.
content: When the secretive national security adviser of the United Arab Emirates, Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed, visited the White House in June, his American counterpart, Jake Sullivan, raised a delicate issue: G42, an artificial intelligence firm controlled by the sheikh that American officials believe is hiding the extent of its work with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Special Forces’ and ‘Selena + Chef’
description: The endurance reality show wraps up its second season. Selena Gomez’s cooking show returns with a holiday special.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 27-Dec. 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Hopes to Alter the Trajectory of the War as Hostages Are Released
description: At the president’s urging, the temporary truce between Israel and Hamas was extended two more days. The challenge is what comes next.
content: After seven weeks of struggling with a crisis that defies easy solutions, President Biden could take solace in saving a single 4-year-old girl whose parents were killed in the Oct. 7 terrorist attack on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyna Bentahar
title: Helping Those in Need
description: The Times’s century-old charity fund has a new name.
content: Last year, Tyhran Khosrovian and Olena Holeha survived the siege of Mariupol. They fled Ukraine, as millions have since the war began, and became refugees in the United States. After arriving in Brooklyn, they slept on a leaky air mattress in an apartment they shared with Khosrovian’s family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Emma Corrin Has a Mystery to Solve
description: The actor has worked steadily since breaking out as a young Princess Diana in “The Crown.” Corrin’s latest role is as an amateur sleuth in “A Murder at the End of the World.”
content: “I have no idea what I like,” Emma Corrin said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones, Christopher Mele and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Heavy Snow Blankets Western and Northern New York
description: The storm is expected to bring up to two feet of snow, and possibly more in some areas. Forecasters said the storm would likely stay just south of Buffalo.
content: Snow began blanketing parts of Northern and Western New York on Monday night as a lake-effect snowstorm that could bring up to two feet bore down on the region, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Biden’s Weakness Among Young Voters Should Be Taken Seriously
description: Almost all the polling shows the same pattern. Could the coming campaign restore Democrats’ usual advantage?
content: Could President Biden and Donald J. Trump really be locked in a close race among young voters — a group Democrats typically carry by double digits — as the recent Times/Siena polls suggest?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikki Campo
title: Can Certain Foods Really Reduce Your Cancer Risk?
description: You won’t find a silver bullet in a single food, experts say, but there are some that may help you build the best defense.
content: On average, more than one in three people in the United States will develop cancer at some point in their lifetime, according to the American Cancer Society. And many of those cases, they say, can potentially be prevented, including by making changes to your diet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: How Your Child’s Online Mistake Can Ruin Your Digital Life
description: Google has a zero-tolerance policy for child abuse content. The scanning process can sometimes go awry and tar innocent individuals as abusers.
content: When Jennifer Watkins got a message from YouTube saying her channel was being shut down, she wasn’t initially worried. She didn’t use YouTube, after all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Feed a Crowd With This Rich Ube Babka Wreath
description: Hanukkah cookies, free hot chocolate and other sweet food news.
content: A glazed, sugared round of twisted babka becomes a dazzling holiday wreath by Kora, a Filipino bakery in Long Island City, Queens. The filling woven throughout the brioche dough is the rich deep violet of puréed ube, the Filipino purple sweet potatoes. The babka is made in collaboration with Umamicart, an online Asian supermarket based in Brooklyn, which sells it and ships nationally. The plump wreath, 10 inches across, will serve at least 12. Just have some whipped cream or ice cream alongside or accompany it with leche flan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Dani Blum
title: A New Match for Menopausal Weight Gain: Ozempic
description: Weight gain is one of the most common concerns among women going through menopause. New drugs could change that.
content: Kymberly Smith had had enough. It was February 2020, and she was grieving the sudden death of her husband when Covid lockdowns began. She was alone, without any access to her support network, and she was “in the throes of menopause.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Good Old Days of Book Publishing, Martinis and All
description: “Among Friends” is a history of an industry transformed by consolidation and shifting tastes.
content: Some of the most stressed-out young people in the United States, if movies can be believed, work in publishing. IMDb, the online database, yokes these films together as a genre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Car Crash Victims Seek Justice in a New Way: Talking to the Drivers
description: Circles for Safe Streets encourages New York drivers who hit people to take responsibility. Those who were injured can speak directly to those at fault.
content: Bill Penny was the center of attention in a tense room. It had been about nine months since he drove the wrong way down a one-way road in Brooklyn, hitting and critically injuring a woman who was crossing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Visits Israel Amid Backlash Against His Endorsement of Antisemitic Post
description: Alongside Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, Mr. Musk toured an Israeli village where dozens of people were killed in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks.
content: Elon Musk traveled to Israel and met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday, touring the scene of a Hamas attack in a visit that appeared aimed at calming the outcry over his endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X, the social media platform he owns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Trial Starts in France for Teenagers Accused of Helping Teacher’s Killer
description: The teacher, Samuel Paty, was beheaded by an Islamist extremist in 2020 after showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad to illustrate free speech. The case horrified the nation.
content: Six teenagers went on trial in Paris on Monday over accusations they were connected to the murder of Samuel Paty, a history teacher whose beheading by an Islamist extremist in 2020 inflicted lasting trauma on France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden to Skip U.N. Climate Summit, White House Official Says
description: He has attended the past two summits and calls climate change “the ultimate threat” but will miss the talks that are set to begin in Dubai on Thursday.
content: President Biden will not attend a major United Nations climate summit that begins Thursday in Dubai, skipping an event expected to be attended by King Charles III, Pope Francis and leaders from nearly 200 countries, a White House official said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: A Deal to Extend the Gaza Truce
description: Plus Indonesia’s female forest rangers.
content: Israel and Hamas agreed yesterday to extend their fragile truce for two more days, according to officials in Qatar who helped negotiate the initial cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Jesse Armstrong Still Has ‘a Lot of Sympathy’ for the Roys
description: In an interview, the “Succession” creator looked back on the end of the show and discussed Marxism, extreme wealth and whether any of his characters were remotely likable.
content: Jesse Armstrong didn’t always know how “Succession” would end. But he knew how that ending would feel. “It was always a bit about human mortality and the mortality of these kinds of media operations,” he said. As early as the pilot, he added, “I knew what the tone of the ending would be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Three-Year Cruise Is Canceled for Lack of a Ship
description: Passengers will not be visiting Machu Picchu, the Pyramids of Giza or indeed be going anywhere.
content: If you’re going to organize a three-year round-the-world cruise, a good first step is probably to acquire a ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susanne Fowler
title: Round and Round We Go: Circular Strolls Near London
description: A handy guidebook outlines 27 bucolic walks outside the British capital that begin and end at train stations. We tried some out.
content: When is walking in circles a good thing? When following a trail through villages, forests and fields using open-access paths that begin and end at the same train station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: My Red Lentil Soup With Five Stars and Nearly 23,000 Reviews
description: It’s the most reviewed recipe in our New York Times Cooking recipe database.
content: Now that the Thanksgiving hubbub has died down, let’s take a moment of lovely calm before we fall headlong into the flickering fray of Hanukkah-Solstice-Christmas-Kwanzaa-New Year’s. In our house, I’m declaring the next two weeks to be family cozy time, the three of us snuggled up on the couch watching pirates and vampires after fuss-free, satisfying dinners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Marc Santora
title: Storm Batters Southern Ukraine, Spreading Misery for Civilians and Soldiers
description: Violent waves stirred by hurricane-force winds threatened to tear maritime mines from their moorings in the Sea of Azov and the Black Sea.
content: A powerful wintry storm battered southern Ukraine on Monday, washing away Russian coastal defenses from some beaches on the occupied Crimean Peninsula. The storm, which Ukrainian meteorologists said was among the most intense in decades, snarled supply routes for both countries’ armies and deepened the misery of tens of thousands of soldiers huddled in shallow trenches across the sprawling front line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Christian Monterrosa
title: Could Biden’s Clean Energy Push Be a Victim of Its Success?
description: Thanks to the president’s signature legislation, solar energy manufacturing is booming in Georgia, a key state in the 2024 election. But the industry now worries that it could be too much and too fast.
content: Dalton, Ga., was once known as the carpet capital of the country. Economic diversification meant branching out from wall-to-wall to hardwood flooring. Now, at Qcells, a solar panel company, robots patrol acres of shop floor where delicate solar cells are packaged, laminated and boxed into sophisticated panels — almost 30,000 a day at peak production — in a highly automated production line.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Analyzing Bernie Sanders’s Vision for Mideast Peace
description: Readers discuss the senator’s guest essay. Also: The civilian toll in Gaza and Ukraine; college in prison; comfortable office design.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Military Is Slow to Act on Risky Arms
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 27, 2023.
content: “It was hugely, hugely surprising. The danger was us. We were doing it to ourselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: congenial
description: This word has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word congenial has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 7 in “Day 7: Finding Inner Peace While You’re Underground” by Jack Denton:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Former Coal Towns Get Money for Clean-Energy Factories
description: An Energy Department program designed to create jobs and manufacturing in communities reliant on fossil fuels is backing projects in West Virginia, Colorado and elsewhere.
content: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Arizona Legislators Must Testify About Voting Laws, Supreme Court Rules
description: Two Republican lawmakers had argued that they could not be questioned about their motives for supporting the laws, which require proof of citizenship to vote in federal elections.
content: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that two Arizona lawmakers must testify about their reasons for supporting state laws requiring proof of citizenship for voting in federal elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Nate Schweber
title: On a Single Day, Two Men Are Cleared in Decades-Old Manhattan Murders
description: Jabar Walker and Wayne Gardine were convicted in an era of crime and corruption that has created a wave of exonerations years later.
content: The killings happened eight blocks apart within nine months, near the height of New York City’s crack wars, in a Harlem precinct that was becoming synonymous with police corruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Young Thug’s YSL RICO Trial: What to Know
description: Hip-hop collective or street gang? In a blockbuster case against the famed Atlanta rap crew YSL, headed by Young Thug, prosecutors say it is both.
content: When the racketeering and gang conspiracy trial of Jeffery Williams, best known as the chart-topping rapper Young Thug, began on Monday in Atlanta, the star defendant had been in jail for 567 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: N.Y. Cannabis Board Settles Suits, Paving Way for Dispensaries to Open
description: Regulators agreed to a settlement that would save 436 retailers from losing their licenses.
content: The New York State cannabis board voted Monday to approve a settlement that would resolve two lawsuits and end a three-month-long freeze on recreational dispensary openings across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Hubbard
title: When They Were Going Through Hell, They Kept a Record
description: Lauren Grodstein’s new novel takes place in the Warsaw ghetto, where a secret group of archivists made sure the truth survived.
content: Two decades before World War II, Lauren Grodstein’s great-grandparents fled Poland’s capital city and the antisemitism that was already ascendant there. “In all likelihood,” she writes in the afterword to this accomplished sixth book, “I would not be here had they stayed.” A chilling what-if, an idea for a book. More than a century after those ancestors escaped to safety, Grodstein gives voice to the doomed denizens they might have become.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Huge Turbines Will Soon Bring First Offshore Wind Power to New Yorkers
description: New York’s best bet for entering the era of offshore wind power is stacked up at the water’s edge in Connecticut.
content: The pier on the Connecticut coast is filled with so many massive oddities that it could be mistaken for the set of a sci-fi movie. Sword-shaped blades as long as a football field lie stacked along one edge, while towering yellow and green cranes hoist giant steel cylinders to stand like rockets on a launchpad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Evan Roberts, Leslye Davis, Nell Gallogly, Dan Powell and Kelly Pieko
title: Introducing: ‘DealBook Summit’
description: This new podcast features a selection of interviews from the 2023 DealBook Summit event, hosted by Andrew Ross Sorkin.
content: “DealBook Summit” includes conversations with business and policy leaders at the heart of today’s major stories, recorded live at the annual DealBook Summit event in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Donnelly
title: Solving the Puzzle of Gift Giving
description: A seven-letter word for love: PRESENT.
content: In 2021, I made my first word puzzle as a gift for my girlfriend for the same reasons many people did things during the pandemic: a lack of cash and an abundance of free time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Border Wall-Related Falls Are Increasing in California
description: Migrants are injuring their heads and shattering their limbs as they try to scale barriers along the border with Mexico.
content: It’s Monday. More migrants are injuring themselves as they try to cross the southern border in California. Plus, an L.A. Rams training complex could help transform urban sprawl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake Returns to No. 1 as Dolly Parton Opens Big With ‘Rockstar’
description: The country star’s rock-themed new LP debuts at No. 3, becoming her highest-charting album on Billboard’s all-genre Top 200.
content: Drake’s latest album, “For All the Dogs,” returns to No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart this week thanks to an expanded edition, while Dolly Parton notches her highest chart position ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Stacy Y. China
title: How Cave Canem Has Nurtured Generations of Black Poets
description: The poets’ fellowship, which was founded in 1996, has worked with poets who have gone on to win many of the genre’s most important accolades.
content: The poet Cornelius Eady took out his phone the other day and clicked to a black-and-white group photo that was taken 43 summers ago when he was a fellow at Bread Loaf, the famous writers’ retreat held each year in Vermont. Eady is easy to spot — he is the only Black person in the picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Navy Rescues Ship From Somali Pirate Attack
description: The United States says the episode is unrelated to regional tensions, though it is still investigating the firing of two missiles at the Navy ship involved in the rescue.
content: The five gunmen who attacked a chemical tanker in the Gulf of Aden on Sunday and were later captured by the U.S. Navy were Somali pirates, American officials said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel and Hamas Agreed to Extend Their Truce, Qatar Says
description: Also, Biden plans to skip the U.N. climate summit. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israel and Hamas agreed today to extend by two days a cease-fire that has brought a measure of calm to the Gaza Strip after seven weeks of intense warfare, according to officials in Qatar who were involved in the negotiations. The two sides struck a deal to exchange more hostages and prisoners and allow more aid into Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vasilisa Kirilochkina
title: Russian Women Get a Fresh Warning About Their Rights
description: Expressing feminist views in Russia is now an increasingly dangerous thing to do.
content: It has been more than six months since the Russian playwright Svetlana Petriychuk and the theater director Zhenya Berkovich were arrested and jailed for their work on “Finist, the Bright Falcon,” an acclaimed play sympathetic to women recruited by ISIS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: X Has Become a ‘Global Sewer,’ Mayor of Paris Says
description: In a scalding post, Mayor Anne Hidalgo announced she would quit the social platform, formerly known as Twitter, for exacerbating “tensions and conflicts.”
content: Anne Hidalgo, the mayor of Paris, announced Monday on X, formerly Twitter, that she was quitting the social media site because it had devolved into a “gigantic global sewer” for disinformation, hatred, anti-Semitism and racism, and a “tool for destroying our democracies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: We Know War Is Awful, So Why Is It Making a Comeback?
description: Leaders can’t always avoid war, but being rational helps.
content: The two bloodiest wars of the past two years have been results of tragic miscalculations. A third war, which has dominated the news lately, might also have been set in motion by a costly mistake, as I’ll explain. To economists, this raises a question: If wars are so awful, why do we keep blundering into them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Scoles
title: Mars Needs Insects
description: If humans are ever going to live on the red planet, they’re going to have to bring bugs with them.
content: At first it was just one flower, but Emmanuel Mendoza, an undergraduate student at Texas A&M University, had worked hard to help it bloom. When this five-petaled thing burst forth from his English pea plant collection in late October, and then more flowers and even pea pods followed, he could also see, a little better, the future it might foretell on another world millions of miles from Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
title: Russian Women Protest Long Deployments for Soldiers in Ukraine
description: “Make way for someone else,” a new grass-roots movement demands as women challenge the official argument that the mobilized troops are needed in combat indefinitely.
content: The woman in the video, her face blurred, gave a blunt assessment of Russian military policy: Soldiers mobilized over a year ago to fight in Ukraine deserved to come home. Why weren’t they?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald P. Moynihan
title: Trump Has a Master Plan for Destroying the ‘Deep State’
description: We should all be paying careful attention to the former president’s plans for a second term.
content: I study government bureaucracies. This is not normally a key political issue. Right now, it is, and everyone should be paying attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Campaign Aims to Weaponize Trump’s Threat to Obamacare
description: The president’s aides quickly jumped on a statement by Donald Trump that he was “seriously looking at alternatives” to the health law.
content: Very few events bring aides on President Biden’s re-election campaign more joy than when former President Donald J. Trump threatens to repeal popular Democratic policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Let’s Talk About Biden, Trump and … Taylor Swift
description: Do any of them deserve to be Time’s person of the year?
content: Bret Stephens: Hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, Gail. Peggy Noonan had a terrific column last week in The Wall Street Journal, making the case for why Taylor Swift should be Time’s person of the year. Aside from the fact that her Eras tour transformed the economy of many of the cities in which she played, she also spoke to the hearts and souls of millions of Swifties — including my two daughters — and spread joy, romance and glamour across the fair land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: After 9 Years in Limbo, Treasures From Crimea Return to Ukraine
description: The artifacts were on loan to a Dutch museum when Russia invaded in 2014. Ukraine argued that they must be kept out of the aggressor’s hands.
content: Hundreds of ancient artifacts from Crimea that were stored in a Dutch museum for nine years while Russia and Ukraine waged a legal battle over their ownership are now back in Ukraine, officials in Amsterdam said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Eurostar to Suspend Amsterdam to London Service for 6 Months
description: The no-transfer rail connection from the Dutch capital to London will close starting in June. A new terminal for Eurostar passengers is set to open at Amsterdam’s main rail station in 2025.
content: Direct train service from Amsterdam to London on the Eurostar, the sleek, fast train that connects Britain to northwestern Europe, will be suspended for six months next year, the train company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg, Traci Carl, Gaya Gupta, Katherine Rosman and Roni Rabin
title: Here’s What We Know About the Hostages Released on Monday
description: The group comprised women and children only, all of them taken from Nir Oz during Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7.
content: Hamas released 11 Israeli hostages — all women and children taken from Kibbutz Nir Oz — on Monday, the fourth day of the cease-fire, according to the Israeli government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Trapped in a Tunnel for 15 Days, With No End in Sight
description: The effort to rescue 41 construction workers in India has faced repeated setbacks. Now the authorities are trying to drill vertically through a mountain.
content: Over the two weeks that dozens of Indian construction workers have been trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the authorities have reported meter-by-meter progress toward reaching them and offered hopeful timelines for their rescue. Each time a breakthrough has appeared imminent, politicians have rushed to the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: A third day of hostage exchanges in Israel.
content: Hamas, the armed group that controls Gaza, released 17 more hostages, including a 4-year-old girl, and said it would seek to extend a temporary cease-fire with Israel. The current four-day pause is scheduled to end today. An additional 39 Palestinians in custody were freed on Sunday, according to Israel’s prison service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: A Final Wave of Sex-Abuse Lawsuits as One-Year Window Closes in New York
description: Since the Adult Survivors Act was passed, more than 3,000 civil suits have been filed, some aimed at politicians and others at institutions including hospitals and jails.
content: In the year since a one-time window opened in New York State allowing people to file sex-abuse lawsuits even after the statute of limitations had expired, more than 3,000 civil suits have been filed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: In Countdown to Iowa, Trump Is Coasting, as DeSantis and Haley Clash
description: The former president’s chief rivals are running low on time to make a statement in Iowa’s caucuses, which could determine whether the Republicans’ nominating contest is seriously contested at all.
content: Negative mailers are overstuffing Iowa mailboxes. Attack ads are cluttering the airwaves. And door knockers are fanning out from Des Moines to Dubuque and everywhere in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Is There Such a Thing as a ‘Useless’ College Major?
description: Would you consider pursuing a degree in a field you love even if it wouldn’t necessarily lead to a well-paying job?
content: If you are planning to go to college, what are you thinking of studying? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: At the Montauk Lighthouse, a Restored Beacon Shines Again
description: A lens made in 1902 has been returned to the lantern room atop the lighthouse, which was commissioned by George Washington.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll find out why a crucial component in the oldest lighthouse in New York State has just been replaced with one manufactured in 1902.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Brazilian
title: The Ceramists Putting a Fresh Spin on Traditional Korean Techniques
description: In reinvigorating the craft’s rich history, a group of female Korean and Korean American artists are creating a body of wholly distinct work.
content: The Brooklyn-based ceramic artist Eun-Ha Paek’s pieces are defined by their renegade spirit. A recent work, a foot-high stoneware form, resembles a child’s stick-figure drawing, but with a Surrealist bent: Instead of a head, it has a blue-and-white delftware-style dinner plate; instead of eyes, there are painted butterflies. “I like combining serve ware with food shapes, as if elements of a meal had come together and were having a dinner party,” says Paek, who builds her works’ hollow extremities, including legs that look like hot dogs, with a machine called an extruder and molds other parts by hand before coating the finished forms with cobalt and iron oxide washes and glazes. The pieces reflect Paek’s training in animation, film and video at the Rhode Island School of Design — now in New York, she teaches ceramics at Doclay and at Greenwich House, and illustration at the Parsons School of Design — as well as her upbringing. Born in Seoul, she immigrated to Los Angeles with her family when she was 9 and was dazzled by the new culture she encountered there. “The first place we went was to a drive-through for hamburgers,” she says. “I think my parents saw it as a symbol of having made it, to live in a country where food was brought to your car.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Rachelle Bonja, Marc Georges, Brad Fisher, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: Botox, Hermès and OnlyFans: Why This May Be George Santos’s Last Week in Congress
description: Representative George Santos is facing a new expulsion push after a damning ethics report.
content: Only five members of the U.S. House of Representatives have ever been expelled from the institution. This week, Representative George Santos, Republican of New York, could become the sixth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Tik Root
title: Vermont Man Charged With Attempted Murder for Shootings of Palestinian Students
description: Jason J. Eaton, 48, of Burlington, was charged with shooting three college students of Palestinian descent on Saturday outside the building where the police said he lives.
content: A 48-year-old Vermont man was charged on Monday with three counts of attempted second-degree murder in the weekend shooting of three young men of Palestinian descent on a Burlington street, a violent episode that stunned the small city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pati Jinich
title: On the Border, the Perfect Burrito is a Thin, Foil-Wrapped Treasure
description: Despite a culinary rivalry, the sister cities El Paso and Ciudad Juárez can agree that a simple burrito is the best burrito.
content: One bite of a chile verde con papas burrito at Burritos Sarita in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, has the power to shatter whatever preconceived notions you have about burritos. In it, a pillowy-soft flour tortilla, with hints of smoke from the griddle, swaddles a fragrant mix of tender potatoes, caramelized onions and fire-roasted chile verde that is coated in a salty and tangy thick crema.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Bowe
title: An Ancient Solution to Our Current Crisis of Disconnection
description: Rhetorical training is tantamount to installing the operating system for adult social life.
content: At the risk of sounding mawkishly positive, I think I’ve discovered a cheap, simple fix for our fraying social, emotional and political health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Portland Teachers’ Strike Ends After More Than Three Weeks
description: Portland students have struggled with absenteeism since the pandemic,
content: The union representing teachers, counselors and other school employees in Portland, Ore., reached a tentative deal with the city's public school district on Sunday, ending a strike that has kept nearly 45,000 students out of classes for more than three weeks in Oregon’s largest district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shreya Chattopadhyay
title: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by An Yu, RJ Young, Pier Paolo Pasolini and more.
content: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by An Yu, RJ Young, Pier Paolo Pasolini and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the 14 Hidden Food-Themed Book Titles in This Puzzle?
description: Just tap or click on the books you discover to learn more about them. You may even find some gift ideas for the foodie in your life.
content: Just tap or click on the books you discover to learn more about them. You may even find some gift ideas for the foodie in your life.
source.name: The New York Times
